issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

fixVersions.description: The release will stabilize core components, improve performances and adds new streaming algorithms. Unmaintained code is getting killed as part of this

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

versions.description: Primarily a cleanup and refactoring release. Some new functionality which has been previously completed and tested may be introduced.

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description: A user reported that QR decomposition is too slow.  I coded up a replacement that can be 10x faster under certain cases and the new version is also tested.

creator.name: tdunning
creator.emailAddress: ted dot dunning at gmail dot com

reporter.name: tdunning
reporter.emailAddress: ted dot dunning at gmail dot com

author.name: tdunning
author.emailAddress: ted dot dunning at gmail dot com

comments.body:
I committed the new QR decomposition.  This is a bit bold to do, but I think that the benefits are large enough to really make a difference.  The tests on the QR decomposition are pretty strict so the results should drop in.  The exception would be if somebody is checking the content of the QR decomposition itself rather than just its results since there are likely sign changes relative to the old implementation.

This impacts the ALS code including the implicit solvers.  I am hoping that we have good tests on those and will see any problems quickly.

I have also not run the full suite of tests.  If Jenkins bitches, I will reopen this bug and fix the issues.

updateAuthor.name: tdunning
updateAuthor.emailAddress: ted dot dunning at gmail dot com

comments.body:
Integrated in Mahout-Quality #1854 (See [https://builds.apache.org/job/Mahout-Quality/1854/])
    MAHOUT-1148 - Demonstrate speedup (Revision 1442436)
MAHOUT-1148 - Re-implemented QR decomposition.  On a 60x60 random matrix it is about 8x faster now after the JIT warms up (takes 100 or so decompositions). (Revision 1442428)

     Result = FAILURE
tdunning : http://svn.apache.org/viewcvs.cgi/?root=Apache-SVN&view=rev&rev=1442436
Files : 
* /mahout/trunk/math/src/main/java/org/apache/mahout/math/OldQRDecomposition.java
* /mahout/trunk/math/src/main/java/org/apache/mahout/math/QR.java
* /mahout/trunk/math/src/main/java/org/apache/mahout/math/QRDecomposition.java
* /mahout/trunk/math/src/test/java/org/apache/mahout/math/QRDecompositionTest.java

tdunning : http://svn.apache.org/viewcvs.cgi/?root=Apache-SVN&view=rev&rev=1442428
Files : 
* /mahout/trunk/math/src/main/java/org/apache/mahout/math/OldQRDecomposition.java
* /mahout/trunk/math/src/main/java/org/apache/mahout/math/QRDecomposition.java
* /mahout/trunk/math/src/test/java/org/apache/mahout/math/OldQRDecompositionTest.java
* /mahout/trunk/math/src/test/java/org/apache/mahout/math/QRDecompositionTest.java

QRDecompositionTest.fullRankWide() is failing.

Here's what I am seeing locally:-

fullRankWide(org.apache.mahout.math.QRDecompositionTest)  Time elapsed: 0.004 sec  <<< FAILURE!
java.lang.AssertionError: null
	at org.junit.Assert.fail(Assert.java:86)
	at org.junit.Assert.assertTrue(Assert.java:41)
	at org.junit.Assert.assertFalse(Assert.java:64)
	at org.junit.Assert.assertFalse(Assert.java:74)
	at org.apache.mahout.math.QRDecompositionTest.fullRankWide(QRDecompositionTest.java:117)

Its failing on this line in QRDecompositionTest.fullRankWide() 

   assertFalse(qr.getFullRank())

comments.body:
Integrated in Mahout-Quality #1855 (See [https://builds.apache.org/job/Mahout-Quality/1855/])
    MAHOUT-1148 - fix test ... should have been full rank (Revision 1442691)

     Result = SUCCESS
tdunning : 
Files : 
* /mahout/trunk/math/src/test/java/org/apache/mahout/math/QRDecompositionTest.java

I ran a quick mini benchmark using ALS to factorize the movielens1M dataset, (I didn't check correctness of the results). Numbers indicate a 2x to 3x increase in performance:

[2] features, [3] iterations: OLD [1233] ms <-> NEW [1254] ms

comments.body: Well, Jake predicted a speedup.  But this is a big difference.

updateAuthor.name: tdunning
updateAuthor.emailAddress: ted dot dunning at gmail dot com

comments.body:
I tried the new QRDecompose implementation in mahout. There is a big improvement comparing with the old one. But it's still slower than the implementation from org.apache.commons.math3.linear.QRDecomposition. Here is my comparison. 
Map input records: 2,827,622
num of Features = 60
Solve time with org.apache.mahout.math.QRDecomposition = 8,459,920
Solve time with org.apache.commons.math3.linear.QRDecomposition = 1,214,592

author.name: tdunning
author.emailAddress: ted dot dunning at gmail dot com

comments.body: The difference was just a matter of rewriting the algorithm using vector operations instead of element by element math.  You can probably get another 2x out of the algorithm pretty easily and possibly 5x with some cleverness.  I didn't spend any time optimizing this code at all.

updateAuthor.name: tdunning
updateAuthor.emailAddress: ted dot dunning at gmail dot com
